Use the following steps to enforce strong passwords:

Define password requirements. Pick the schema that all passwords must follow. Check them for length and certain patterns. All passwords should be long (e.g. 8+ characters in length) and include a large input set (e.g. alpha-numeric and special character values).
Enforce password requirements. The password requirements should be enforced while creating and modifying accounts. Consult the database manual on setting up the appropriate password policy.

html:
Applies to

  • Applications written using Servlets or JSP which interact with a database.

What to Do

Enforce strong passwords when the application connects to a backend database server.

Why

Enforcing strong passwords minimizes the risk of a dictionary attack or guessing the credentials of an application's accounts.

When

If your application uses a backend database server, enforce strong SQL passwords.

How

What constitutes a strong password varies from organization to organization; however, there are generally agreed upon minimum requirements for length and input character sets:

  • The password must be at least 10 characters long.
  • It must contain letters, numbers, and special characters.
  • Use the following steps to enforce strong passwords:

  1. Define password requirements. Pick the schema that all passwords must follow. Check them for length and certain patterns. All passwords should be long (e.g. 8+ characters in length) and include a large input set (e.g. alpha-numeric and special character values).

  2. Enforce password requirements. The password requirements should be enforced while creating and modifying accounts. Consult the database manual on setting up the appropriate password policy.

  3. Enforce password lifetime. Determine a lifetime of a password. Once a password is expired, make sure the new password varies from the old password. Consult the database manual on how to properly set the password lifetime.

Problem Example

MyApp is a multi-user financial tool. Unfortunately, it does not enforce strong passwords for its database access; therefore, it is easier for an attacker to obtain the application's database credentials by guessing or conducting a dictionary attack.

Solution Example

MyApp is a multi-user financial tool. Because it enforces strong passwords for its database access, it is harder for an attacker to obtain the application's database credentials via guessing or through a dictionary attack.

  • Use Least Privileged Accounts for Database Access
